summary: This document is a series of emails from whistleblower Christopher J. Dilorio to various judges and SEC officials, alleging massive ongoing securities fraud, accounting fraud, and money laundering involving Virtu Financial (VIRT/NITE), Knight Capital (KCG), and their associates. Dilorio claims the SEC and SDNY are engaged in criminal obstruction to protect these entities and individuals like Rich Handler of Jefferies, while denying his whistleblower claims and covering up the true nature of their business: abusive naked short selling of OTC market shells to facilitate money laundering.

persons.name: Christopher J. Dilorio
persons.context: Author of the emails, making extensive allegations of securities fraud, accounting fraud, and money laundering involving Virtu Financial, Knight Capital, and others. Claims the SEC and SDNY are obstructing investigation.

persons.name: Cifu
persons.context: Referenced as making admissions about Virtu's revenue model being driven by retail participation and OTCM trading. Allegedly involved in balance sheet fraud and the VIRT/KCG merger.

persons.name: Rich Handler
persons.context: Alleged to have a corrupt relationship with the SEC/SDNY. Described as a primary beneficiary of frauds related to Knight Capital and the VIRT/KCG merger.

persons.name: Dan Kamensky
persons.context: Subject of a joint SEC/SDNY complaint. Dilorio claims his information led to Kamensky's plea deal but that exculpatory evidence is being withheld.

persons.name: Sean Galvin
persons.context: Identified as the third NITE/VIRT CFO in just over a year, allegedly keeping the accounting fraud running.

persons.name: Blostein
persons.context: A sell-side analyst covering NITE/VIRT. Dilorio accuses him of knowing about but not modeling OTCM share volumes that drive Virtu's revenue.

persons.name: Reppetto
persons.context: Referenced as a 'perma pumper' who asked questions on earnings calls. Implied to have a relationship with Handler/Jefferies.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Addressed in emails regarding the lack of investigation into Dilorio's allegations and the Dan Kamensky case.

persons.name: Judge Cave
persons.context: Addressed in emails regarding the corrupt relationship between the SEC and Handler/Jefferies, and the Kamensky case.

persons.name: Judge Jones
persons.context: Addressed in emails providing 'irrefutable proof' of SEC corruption regarding the VIRT/KCG merger.

persons.name: Jay Clayton
persons.context: Accused of conflicts of interest due to his previous firm Sullivan & Cromwell's ties to NITE/VIRT, and of not recusing himself from related matters.

persons.name: Glenn Hutchins
persons.context: Described as a friend of Jay Clayton and a former Blackstone employee. His firm North Island is a top shareholder in NITE/VIRT, linked to money laundering allegations.

persons.name: Robert Greifeld
persons.context: Former director of Automated Securities Clearance Ltd, which was sold to SunGard. Later became CEO of NASDAQ. Co-founded North Island with Hutchins, a top NITE/VIRT investor.

persons.name: Adena Friedman
persons.context: Signed off on NASDAQ's transaction to buy the BRUT ECN from SunGard.

persons.name: Jared Fishman
persons.context: Identified as a colleague of Jay Clayton who played a key role in keeping NITE/VIRT operational.

persons.name: Hoecker
persons.context: Recipient of Dilorio's emails. Accused of being corrupt and precluded from involvement due to Clayton's conflicts.

persons.name: Janey
persons.role: SEC Official (likely in Office of the Whistleblower)
persons.context: Primary recipient of many emails. Accused of failing to produce the full record for Dilorio's whistleblower award denial and facilitating obstruction.

persons.name: Joshie Sason
persons.context: Linked to Hanover/Magna and various shell companies (CGFIA, IMDS, etc.). Subject of an SEC complaint regarding bogus notes, which Dilorio claims is based on his information.

persons.name: Justin Keener
persons.context: Detailed in Dilorio's 2013 TCR. Involved in money laundering shells like Blink Charging. Barred by FINRA as a 'Bad Actor'.

persons.name: Norberg
persons.context: Credited with creating 'extraordinary reasons' for denying Dilorio's whistleblower award, including claiming SEC investigators never saw his information.

persons.name: Berger
persons.context: SEC official with whom Dilorio filed his 2013 TCR.

persons.name: Fannon
persons.context: Mentioned alongside Reppetto as having a BUY rating on NITE/VIRT and being questioned about their relationship with Handler/Jefferies.

connections.description: Dilorio is a whistleblower who has submitted multiple TCRs and hundreds of emails alleging fraud, but claims the SEC is engaged in criminal obstruction and denial of his awards.
Dilorio alleges a corrupt, criminal relationship exists between Handler/Jefferies and the SEC/SDNY, leading to protection of NITE/VIRT and obstruction of investigations.
Alleged to have orchestrated the VIRT/KCG merger using fraudulent balance sheet items, with Handler/Jefferies as a major shareholder and beneficiary.
Colleagues at Sullivan & Cromwell. Fishman is alleged to have played a key role in keeping NITE/VIRT operational.
Co-founded North Island, a top shareholder in NITE/VIRT. Connected through SunGard and NASDAQ transactions.
Both are described as 'bag men' involved in facilitating money laundering through shell companies and bogus convertible notes.
Handler's firm, Jefferies, was the investment bank in the Kamensky case. Dilorio suggests a corrupt relationship influenced the case.
Dilorio claims his information led to Kamensky's plea deal and that Kamensky is entitled to exculpatory evidence Dilorio possesses.

events.title: Knight Capital 'Glitch'
events.description: A trading glitch at Knight Capital that caused a massive loss, which Dilorio claims was a cover-up for the firm's insolvency due to illegal naked shorting.

events.title: VIRT/KCG Merger Closing
events.description: Virtu Financial's $1.4 billion acquisition of KCG Holdings. Dilorio alleges the deal was based on fraudulent tangible book value calculations and that $4+ billion in 'naked short fails' were written off just prior.

events.title: Ongoing Balance Sheet Fraud
events.description: Dilorio points to Virtu's Q4 2020 and Q1-Q3 2020 earnings reports, showing persistently inflated receivables (alleged naked short fails) and lack of tangible book value disclosure.

events.title: SEC Preliminary Denial of Dilorio's Award
events.description: The SEC's Office of the Whistleblower issued a preliminary denial of Dilorio's award claim related to his 2015 TCR, which he appeals as fabricated and obstructive.

events.title: SEC Complaint Against SeeThroughEquity
events.description: The SEC brought a complaint against SeeThroughEquity, LLC for pump-and-dump schemes. Dilorio notes they promoted Net Element (NETE), a company he had alerted the SEC about as a fraud.

events.title: FINRA Bars Justin Keener/JMJ
events.description: FINRA barred Justin Keener/JMJ as a 'Bad Actor' for failing to provide information related to bogus convertible notes and money laundering shell activities.

keyFacts: The core allegation is that Virtu Financial (NITE) and its predecessor Knight Capital (KCG) are engaged in massive, ongoing accounting fraud and securities fraud by booking 'naked short fails' as receivables on their balance sheet, making them appear solvent while being grossly insolvent.

Christopher Dilorio alleges a corrupt relationship between the SEC/SDNY and Rich Handler of Jefferies, claiming this relationship leads to obstruction of investigations into NITE/VIRT and protection of the firm's illegal activities, which include abusive naked short selling of OTC market shells to facilitate money laundering.

Dilorio claims the 2017 VIRT/KCG merger was fraudulent, with the acquisition price based on a grossly inflated tangible book value that included $4+ billion in 'naked short fails' that were written off just before the deal closed, with Jefferies as a major shareholder and beneficiary.

The document asserts that the SEC has used Dilorio's whistleblower information to bring actions against peripheral players (e.g., Sason, Keener, SeeThroughEquity) while actively obstructing any investigation into the central entity, NITE/VIRT, and denying his whistleblower awards.

High-level connections are drawn between NITE/VIRT investors and former officials, including Glenn Hutchins (friend of Jay Clayton) and former NASDAQ CEO Robert Greifeld through their firm North Island, and alleged money laundering links to Russian ruble conversion via SunGard.
